name: Hyssop (Ezov)
uses: Passover - applied lamb's blood to doorposts with hyssop bunch
Red Heifer purification - essential in creating purification waters
Tzaraat cleansing - ritual purification from spiritual impurity
Temple incense (Ketoret) - component of sacred incense blend
Psalm 51:7 - 'Purge me with hyssop and I shall be clean'
sacredSignificance: Biblical purification plant. Used in most important Jewish purification rituals. Symbolizes humility (grows from walls). Essential to Temple service. Represents divine cleansing and forgiveness.
preparationMethods: Biblical bundle: tied together, dipped in blood or purification water
Hyssop tea: 1-2 tsp dried leaves per cup, steep 10 minutes
Za'atar blend: primary ingredient in Middle Eastern spice mix
Not used ritually since Temple destruction (70 CE)
safetyWarnings: essential oil toxic - do not ingest

jewish.usage: Temple purification, red heifer ritual, Passover blood application, tzaraat cleansing
jewish.significance: Symbol of humility and divine purification. Contrasted with cedar (pride) in rituals.

christian.usage: Vinegar offered to Jesus on hyssop branch at crucifixion
christian.significance: Connects to Passover lamb imagery, baptismal purification symbolism

kabbalistic.significance: Associated with Chesed (loving-kindness) and divine mercy washing away sin

icon:
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 64 64">
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="28.8" fill="#9370DB" opacity="0.2"/>
  <circle cx="32" cy="32" r="19.2" fill="none" stroke="#9370DB" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="5,5"/>
  <text x="32" y="44.8" text-anchor="middle" font-size="22.4" fill="#9370DB">✨</text>
</svg>
description: Hyssop (Ezov) is a sacred plant used in jewish spiritual practices.

name: Mandrake (Dudaim)
uses: HISTORICAL STUDY ONLY - DO NOT USE
Genesis 30: Rachel and Leah bargain for mandrakes
Song of Solomon: erotic imagery with mandrakes
Historical (dangerous): fertility charm, love magic, anesthetic
sacredSignificance: Biblical love and fertility plant. Rachel desperately wanted mandrakes for fertility, but Leah (not Rachel) conceived instead - teaching that fertility comes from God, not herbs. Symbolizes human desire vs divine will.
preparationMethods: Can cause delirium, hallucinations, seizures, coma, death
This entry is for HISTORICAL and MYTHOLOGICAL study ONLY
safetyWarnings: No safe dose - can be fatal
Keep away from children and pets

jewish.usage: Biblical narrative (Genesis 30, Song of Solomon). Not used in practice.
jewish.significance: Lesson that fertility is divine gift, not magical result. Symbol of love and desire.

greek.usage: Myth of Myrrha/Adonis. Historical surgical anesthetic (dangerous).
greek.significance: Transformation, tears of sorrow becoming healing (mythology)

folklore.usage: Screaming root legend, dog harvesting method, anthropomorphic root
folklore.significance: Dangerous power requiring special knowledge to harvest

description: Mandrake (Dudaim) is a figure from ancient mythology.
